_comment: Proper noun variant mappings for Griffith translations - LITERAL TRANSLATION FOCUS
_usage: When a proper noun is detected, search for all its variants to improve retrieval
_sources: Griffith's Rigveda + Griffith's Yajurveda (literal translations) + Satapatha-Brahmana
_philosophy: Griffith provides literal, scholarly translations preserving original Sanskrit terminology and historical context

Vasishtha.note: HIGHEST PRIORITY - Griffith-R is ONLY translation using 'Vasistha' heavily

Gautama.group: Saptarishi (Seven Sages) - Gautama is one of the seven
Gautama.context: Prominent priestly family in Rigveda, composers of multiple hymns
Gautama.hymn_composers: Composed/recited hymns to Maruts (RV 1.88), Agni (RV 1.78, 1.79), Indra (RV 1.61, 1.62, 1.63)
Gautama.distinguishing_features: Known for 'making their prayer with singing', pushed the well's lid up to drink water (RV 1.88.4)
Gautama.yajurveda_presence: Only in commentary/footnotes listing seven sages, not in primary verses
Gautama.note: Often confused as Yajurveda content - actually from Rigveda. Yajurveda only mentions in editorial notes.

Bharadvaja.pattern: Nearly universal agreement on 'Bharadvaja' (149 vs 4 Bharadvija)

Yajnavalkya.context: Founder of White Yajurveda school, major philosopher

Bharatas.context: Victorious in Battle of Ten Kings, led by King Sudas; also priestly clan skilled in song

Trtsus.description: White-robed, braided hair, skilled in song and battle

sources.note: OMITTED from Sharma translations (consolidated into 'Bharata sages')

Bharatas.evolution: Merged with Purus to form Kurus
Bharatas.note: Multi-faceted identity: military tribe AND priestly lineage. Not strictly separate from 'Bharata sages'. Trtsus = Bharata priests in Griffith.

Ganga.context: Most sacred river in Vedic tradition; mentioned in Rigveda, Yajurveda, and later texts. Associated with purification, ritual, and migration eastward (Doab region).
Ganga.note: Variants include both Sanskrit and Anglicized forms. Jahnavi is a poetic epithet. Bhagirathi is a mythic source name.

Purus.context: Rivals of Bharatas, later merged to form Kurus
Purus.note: DIFFERENT from Purusha (cosmic being) - see homonyms

Kurus.context: Formed from merger of Bharatas and Purus after Rigvedic period

rigveda_lineage.kuru_identity: The 'Kuru-ness' (Kauravya) is the common thread connecting these figures
rigveda_lineage.historical_interpretation: Griffith and historians see these as pieces of the same puzzle—the rise of the Kuru dynasty

Kurus.historical_evolution: Rigveda: Individual Kuru-affiliated leaders (Kaurayan, Kurusravana) → Yajurveda: Full Kuru kingdom
Kurus.yajurveda_prominence: Major tribal/royal entity in Yajurveda ritual contexts
Kurus.note: Dynasty traces from Trasadasyu → Kurusravana → Kaurayan lineage in RV, emerges as unified kingdom in YV

formation.historical_process: Multiple Rigvedic tribes merged to form Panchala identity by Yajurveda period

Krivis.migration: Moved east to Doab (Ganges-Yamuna region) by Yajurveda period

Turvashas.origin: One of the Five Tribes (Pancha-janah) in Rigveda
Turvashas.history: Enemies of Sudas in Battle of Ten Kings, later merged into Panchala

Srinjayas.alliance: Closely allied with Bharatas in Rigveda

Somakas.role: Royal lineage providing Panchala kings in later literature

Panchalas.era: Formed by Yajurveda period from Rigvedic tribes
Panchalas.note: Complex confederation formed from former rivals and allies; appears in YV ritual contexts as established kingdom

Trtsus.context: Led by Sudas in Battle of Ten Kings; white-robed singers with braided hair
Trtsus.identity: Both military AND priestly - sang hymns AND fought battles

key_verses.military: These Trtsus under Indra's careful guidance came speeding like loosed waters (RV 7.18.15)
key_verses.priestly: white-robed Trtsus with their braided hair, skilled in song (RV 7.83.8)
key_verses.identity: the Bharatas were found defenceless: then widely were the Trtsus' clans extended (RV 7.33.6)

Trksi.role: Tribe/Clan (identified with Ikshvaku in later Puranic traditions)
Trksi.context: Mentioned in Rigveda Mandala X; later Puranic traditions identify Trksi with the Ikshvaku line
Trksi.note: Added mapping: Trksi (Trksis) often associated with Ikshvaku/Ikshvakus in secondary traditions; counts are approximate and should be validated against the corpus indexing

Magadha.context: Eastern frontier, possibly descended from Kikatas
Magadha.status: Considered outsiders in early Vedic period

Krivis.rigveda_context: Located in Indus and Chenab region
key_references: RV 1.101.1: 'laid Krivi on the earth' (Indra's conquest)
Krivis.migration: Moved east to Doab (Ganges-Yamuna) by Yajurveda period
Krivis.historical_role: Dominant core tribe that formed Panchala confederation
Krivis.note: Early Rigvedic enemy of Indra → migrated east → became Panchala core

Turvashas.role: Tribe (one of Five Tribes/Pancha-janah, constituent of Panchalas)
Turvashas.rigveda_context: One of the famous 'Five Tribes' (Pancha-janah); enemies of Sudas in Battle of Ten Kings
Turvashas.key_characteristic: Former enemies of Bharatas who later merged into Panchala confederation
Turvashas.historical_significance: Demonstrates how rival tribes could unify into larger confederacies
Turvashas.becomes: Constituent tribe of Panchalas (see Panchalas entry)
Turvashas.note: Frequently mentioned in Rigveda; transformation from enemy to confederate is historically significant

Srinjayas.historical_role: Allied clan that merged into Panchala confederation
Srinjayas.becomes: Constituent clan of Panchalas (see Panchalas entry)
Srinjayas.note: Bharata allies who became part of Panchala formation

Somakas.rigveda_context: Prince Sahadeva Somaka mentioned in RV 10.60
key_references: RV 10.60.9: 'the princely son of Sahadeva, Somaka'
Somakas.historical_role: Royal lineage that provided Panchala kings in later literature
Somakas.becomes: Royal lineage of Panchalas (see Panchalas entry)
Somakas.note: Single mention but historically important as source of Panchala royal line

Keshins.rigveda_context: Long-haired ascetics (Munis) with specialized ritual knowledge
Keshins.historical_role: Ritual knowledge specialists who merged into Panchala confederation
Keshins.becomes: Ritual specialists of Panchalas (see Panchalas entry)
Keshins.note: Ascetic group contributing ritual expertise to Panchala formation

key_references: RV 3.53.19: 'Enclose thee in the heart of Khayar timber'
RV 5.43.11: Khadira wood for Soma sacrifice
RV 3.53.19: 'in the car wrought of Sinsapa put firmness'
Simshapa.geography: Native to Indian subcontinent, Himalayan foothills
Simshapa.properties: Strong, beautiful grain, water-resistant, premium quality

Udumbara.properties: Large deciduous tree, sacred in Hindu tradition, strong wood

Wheel_Spokes.context: Multiple wheel configurations mentioned in Rigveda - CRITICAL: both 5-spoked and 12-spoked wheels referenced
key_references: RV 1.164.11: 'Formed with twelve spokes' (12-spoked wheel of Order/Time)
RV 1.164.13: 'Upon this five-spoked wheel revolving ever' (5-spoked wheel)
RV 1.164.48: 'spokes three hundred and sixty' (360 spokes = days in year)

historical_significance.twelve_spokes: Matches Sintashta war chariot archaeology (10-12 spokes, ~2000 BCE)
historical_significance.five_spokes: Does NOT match Sintashta chariots - possibly ceremonial/symbolic

Wheel_Spokes.archaeological_context: Sintashta-Petrovka culture (modern Russia/Kazakhstan, ~2100-1800 BCE) had 10-12 spoked wheels
Wheel_Spokes.vedic_context: Hymn 1.164 is cosmological/mystical - wheels may represent cosmic order, not just physical chariots
Wheel_Spokes.note: BOTH numbers must be mentioned when discussing wheel spokes - they appear in same hymn with different symbolic meanings

Bharata.context: Individual Rshi, hymn composer with Devavata
Bharata.disambiguation: ONLY when explicitly appearing as 'Bharata (Rshi)' with 'Devavata' in Yajurveda-Sharma
Bharata.note: This is a SPECIFIC sage named Bharata, distinct from the Bharata priestly lineage

Bharata.role: Multi-faceted: Military tribe AND Priestly lineage
Bharata.context: Defeated Purus in Ten Kings Battle (military); White-robed singers skilled in hymns (priestly); Trtsus sub-clan
Bharata.disambiguation: Default for most contexts - Bharatas were BOTH warriors AND priests
Bharata.translation_style: Historical (Griffith preserves dual nature via 'Trtsus'); Philosophical (Sharma consolidates)
Bharata.note: NOT strictly separate from 'sages'. Trtsus = Bharata priest-warriors in Griffith

Purusha_vs_Puru.context: Supreme Self, Embodied Spirit, Cosmic Man, Purusha Sukta
Purusha_vs_Puru.disambiguation: When appearing with Prakriti, philosophical context, or 'cosmic' keywords

Purusha_vs_Puru.context: Historical rivals of Bharatas, Ten Kings Battle
Purusha_vs_Puru.disambiguation: When appearing in battle/tribal context, with 'defeated by Bharatas'

Prajapati.disambiguation: When appearing as '(Prajapati Devata)' or in deity context

Sudas.achievement: Victory in Battle of Ten Kings

battle_context.note: RV 7.18.13 says 'conquer scorned Puru' - refers to hostile Puru FACTION, not all Purus

Sudas.historical_context: Purus and Bharatas later formed Kuru confederation (Yajurveda period)
Sudas.note: CRITICAL: Sudas was BHARATA king fighting hostile Puru faction. NOT a Puru king. Purus+Bharatas later united as Kurus.

Pakasthaman_Kaurayan.dynasty_context: Part of Kuru dynasty lineage alongside Trasadasyu and Kurusravana
Pakasthaman_Kaurayan.context: Historical king or chieftain of Kuru clan who provided material support to Vedic poets
Pakasthaman_Kaurayan.gift: Ruddy horse to Indra and Maruts
Pakasthaman_Kaurayan.relation_to_kurus: Kaurayan suffix indicates descent/affiliation with Kuru clan; represents 'Kuru-ness' (Kauravya) that connects to later Kuru kingdom
Pakasthaman_Kaurayan.related_figures: See Trasadasyu (ancestor), Kurusravana (contemporary king), Kurus (later kingdom)
Pakasthaman_Kaurayan.note: Kuru clan later becomes major tribe/kingdom in Yajurveda (Kurus mentioned 4× in ritual contexts)

Kurusravana.context: Part of the emerging Kuru royal lineage in late Rigvedic period
Kurusravana.historical_significance: Represents the continuity of Kuru dynasty from Rigveda to Yajurveda period
Kurusravana.name_etymology: Kuru + sravana (hearing/fame) = 'Fame of the Kurus' or 'Hearing about Kurus'
Kurusravana.kuru_connection: Name explicitly contains 'Kuru', linking to Kaurayan (Pakasthaman) and later Kuru kingdom
Kurusravana.note: Griffith identifies this as part of Kuru dynasty rise; the 'Kuru-ness' (Kauravya) connects Pakasthaman Kaurayan → Kurusravana → later Kuru kingdom

Trasadasyu.context: Celebrated warrior king whose descendants include Kuru dynasty members
Trasadasyu.fame: Named in genealogies as illustrious ancestor
Trasadasyu.dynasty_role: Progenitor figure in Kuru royal lineage
Trasadasyu.note: Famous ancestor establishing legitimacy of later Kuru dynasty through genealogical descent

Rigveda_Sharma.consolidation: Treats Bharatas as unified entity (consolidates Trtsus into 'Bharata sages')

Rigveda_Griffith.unique: Trtsus tribe (10×) - warrior-priests distinct from Bharatas, Ten Kings Battle explicit
Rigveda_Griffith.preservation: Preserves dual nature of Bharatas via separate 'Trtsus' designation

Yajurveda_Sharma.unique: Yajnavalkya (31×), individual sage 'Bharata (Rshi)' with Devavata (5×), most complete (1,830 verses)
Yajurveda_Sharma.consolidation: Distinguishes individual sage from Bharata collective

Yajurveda_Griffith.unique: Kurus/Panchalas (4× each), practical instructions, Bharatas in ritual context (8×)

bharata_identity_notes.historical_reality: Bharatas were multi-faceted: military tribe AND priestly lineage
bharata_identity_notes.trtsus_role: Trtsus = warrior-priest sub-clan within Bharata confederacy
bharata_identity_notes.sharma_approach: Consolidates: 'Bharata' covers both military and spiritual aspects
bharata_identity_notes.exception: Yajurveda-Sharma has individual sage 'Bharata (Rshi)' - distinct from collective

key_evidence.military: Led by King Sudas, defeated Purus in Ten Kings Battle (RV 7.18)
key_evidence.priestly: White-robed Trtsus with braided hair, skilled in song (RV 7.83.8)
key_evidence.unity: The Bharatas were found defenceless; then widely were the Trtsus' clans extended (RV 7.33.6)
